DataElement.preferredName: Gynecologic Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) 2009 Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Anatomic extent of the primary trophoblastic disease based on surgical pathologic examination.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Gynecologic Neoplasm Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor Stage
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Of or relating to or practicing gynecology; pertaining to the health issues of women._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._A diverse group of lesions characterized by excessive proliferation of trophoblasts.  These include premalignant lesions: hydatidiform mole (complete and partial) and malignant disorders: invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumor and miscellaneous trophoblastic lesions.  These tumors are very chemosensitive.  All produce Human Chorionic Gonadotrophin which is utilized as a tumor marker. - 2003._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Of or relating to or practicing gynecology; pertaining to the health issues of women.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: Of or relating to or practicing gynecology; pertaining to the health issues of women.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: A group of interrelated trophoblastic diseases arising from pregnancy. They are commonly associated with hyperplasia of trophoblasts (TROPHOBLAST) and markedly elevated human CHORIONIC GONADOTROPIN. They include HYDATIDIFORM MOLE, invasive mole (HYDATIDIFORM MOLE, INVASIVE), placental-site trophoblastic tumor (TROPHOBLASTIC TUMOR, PLACENTAL SITE), and CHORIOCARCINOMA. These neoplasms have varying propensities for invasion and spread.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: A diverse group of pregnancy-related tumors characterized by excessive proliferation of trophoblasts. It includes gestational choriocarcinoma, epithelioid trophoblastic tumor, placental site trophoblastic tumor, and mixed trophoblastic tumor.
The extent of a cancer in the body.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for CRF standard harmonization. Released per request by D.Reeves. mc 6/5/12

ValueDomain.preferredName: Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) 2009 Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A diverse group of lesions characterized by excessive proliferation of trophoblasts.  These include premalignant lesions: hydatidiform mole (complete and partial) and malignant disorders: invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumor and miscellaneous trophoblastic lesions.  These tumors are very chemosensitive.  All produce Human Chorionic Gonadotrophin which is utilized as a tumor marker. - 2003_An international organization with a mission to promote the wellbeing of women and to raise the standards of practice in obstetrics and gynecology. They are the creator of staging criteria to describe the extent and spread of gynecologic malignancies._A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::2009_The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: FIGO Stage I Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor

ValueMeaning.preferredName: FIGO Stage I Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lesion is confined to the uterus.

Concepts.longName: FIGO Stage I Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor
Concepts.definition: Lesion is confined to the uterus.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: FIGO Stage II Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor

ValueMeaning.preferredName: FIGO Stage II Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lesion invades outside of the uterus, but it is limited to the genital structures.

Concepts.longName: FIGO Stage II Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor
Concepts.definition: Lesion invades outside of the uterus, but it is limited to the genital structures.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: FIGO Stage III Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor

ValueMeaning.preferredName: FIGO Stage III Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lesion affects the lungs, with or without known genital structures invasion.

Concepts.longName: FIGO Stage III Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor
Concepts.definition: Lesion affects the lungs, with or without known genital structures invasion.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: FIGO Stage IV Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor

ValueMeaning.preferredName: FIGO Stage IV Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Gestational trophoblastic tumor in all other metastatic sites.

Concepts.longName: FIGO Stage IV Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor
Concepts.definition: Gestational trophoblastic tumor in all other metastatic sites.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics Integer::2009 Stage
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A group of interrelated trophoblastic diseases arising from pregnancy. They are commonly associated with hyperplasia of trophoblasts (TROPHOBLAST) and markedly elevated human CHORIONIC GONADOTROPIN. They include HYDATIDIFORM MOLE, invasive mole (HYDATIDIFORM MOLE, INVASIVE), placental-site trophoblastic tumor (TROPHOBLASTIC TUMOR, PLACENTAL SITE), and CHORIOCARCINOMA. These neoplasms have varying propensities for invasion and spread.:An international organization with a mission to promote the wellbeing of women and to raise the standards of practice in obstetrics and gynecology.  They are the creator of staging criteria to describe the extent and spread of gynecologic malignancies.:A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::2009:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: A diverse group of pregnancy-related tumors characterized by excessive proliferation of trophoblasts. It includes gestational choriocarcinoma, epithelioid trophoblastic tumor, placental site trophoblastic tumor, and mixed trophoblastic tumor.

An international organization with a mission to promote the wellbeing of women and to raise the standards of practice in obstetrics and gynecology. They are the creator of staging criteria to describe the extent and spread of gynecologic malignancies.
A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
